name: Kepler-380
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-380 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-380 is a star with 1.454 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.22 times its radius. It is located 2717.27 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-380 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-380 b

Kepler-380 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.93 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-380.

The mass of Kepler-380 b is 1.46 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-380 b is 1.19 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-380 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-380 c

Kepler-380 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.63 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-380.

The mass of Kepler-380 c is 1.70 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-380 c is 1.27 that of Earth. At 1.70 Earth masses, Kepler-380 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-380, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
